text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with peach Fein and Sears that's
right we're doing feed on Sears which I
believe is French for loan shark and
these delicious little almond cakes get
their name because they are rich and
they look like gold bars well actually
they're supposed to look like gold bars
if you have the traditional rectangular
molds to make them in which you don't
and neither do I so we'll be using a
little mini muffin pans instead but
geometric issues aside this is a very
easy recipe and it's going to work
beautifully with pretty much any summer
fruit okay so let's go ahead and get
started with step one which is browning
the butter so in a saucepan over medium
heat we're going to melt a little bit of
butter and our butter is going to melt
and then it's going to get foamy and
eventually will be bubbly and
enthusiastically like this and we want
to keep toasting it like I said over
medium heat to a beautiful golden brown
and by the way it's not really the
butter fat that's toasting it's the milk
solids in the butter so that's what
we're keeping our eye on and by swirling
it you should get a pretty good look and
we want to keep toasting it until it
looks like this just a beautiful golden
brown at that point we're going to turn
off the heat and just let it sit there
for about 10 minutes while we put
together the rest of the batter which
starts with separating three eggs and
for this we're just going to use the
whites but don't throw away the yolks
and what am I going to use those for
what am I not going to use them for you
know that didn't sound quite as creepy
in my head but anyway we'll save those
for a custard or something and then to
our egg whites we're going to add some
white sugar and we're going to take a
whisk and kind of stir and beat this
thoroughly and now don't worry we're not
trying to make a meringue here I know
many of you are terrified of meringues
for some reason and what's going to
happen over the course of the next
couple minutes is that sugar is going to
dissolve and those egg whites are going
to get kind of thick and foamy and
you're going to keep whisking until you
have something that looks like this
at which point we'll stop and add the
rest of the ingredients so first up
we'll toss in a big pinch of salt we're
also going to do a little vanilla
extract and then one of the stars of the
show some almond meal which is nothing
more than finely ground almonds and yes
you can totally make that yourself in a
food processor although because I'm lazy
I do get mine pre-made from my friend
Bob
he owns a mill and then we're also going
to need a little bit of
our just regular all-purpose flour and
then once all that's in we'll go ahead
and give that a mix before adding our
now slightly cooled golden brown butter
so I'm gonna go ahead and strain that in
and by the way you don't have to strain
it but it's really not a bad idea so
we'll go ahead and add our butter and
we'll whisk that together and as soon as
that's all mixed together we can go
ahead and fill our muffin tins but
before we do that let's go ahead and
generously butter these now what many
people like to do is they will just
toast a little extra butter and then
just brush that melted butter into the
molds but I don't like to do that I like
to use regular unmelted butter which I
think helps prevent sticking but as with
most of my theories I can't prove it and
then to hedge our bets I'm going to add
a pinch of flour into the bottom of each
one and once I have a little bit in each
one I'm going to go ahead and give it
the old tap etapa and once it gets
knocked around for a few seconds that
flour is going to have coated the bottom
and we shouldn't have any problems with
sticking and then once our pan has been
properly prepped we'll go ahead and pour
in our batter and ideally you want to
fill these up just shy the top okay you
don't want to fill them all the way up
to the brim but I didn't do that even
though I know better I filled them all
the way to the top why human nature but
it's really not that big of a deal as
you'll see and at that point I'm gonna
go ahead and clean this up a little bit
with a paper towel because there's
definitely going to be some drips I find
this to be one of the trickiest batters
of all time
but anyway next on the agenda is to give
it yet another old tap a tappa and that
should take care of any air bubbles and
then we will be topping these with fruit
but not quite yet
what we want to do is bake these for
about five minutes so they get a little
bit set before we try to fruit the top
so let's go ahead and transfer those
into the center of a 400 degree oven for
five minutes and while I'm waiting I'm
going to go ahead and slice my peach so
I'm going to use a beautiful yellow
peach and I'm going to slice a wedge and
take off the skin and then all I'm going
to do is make slices like this so we
really don't want too much this is
really more of a garnish so that right
there is just about the perfect amount
so I went ahead and I did 12 pieces just
like that
and by this point my finance ears have
cooked for five minutes and we'll pull
those out and if everything's gone
according to plan it should look
something like this
and at this point is perfectly safe to
top each one with a piece of fruit in
case you're wondering you can just put
the fruit out at the beginning but
what's going to happen is it's going to
sink down and you won't get his nice of
a presentation and as you may know in
the world of high finance presentation
is important and of course if you don't
like peach you can use something else
you either Richard Gere of your
financier so use any fruit you like
things like apricots plums blueberries
raspberries blackberries so really any
fruits going to work here except durian
durian stinks in this oh yeah just a
little smelly tropical fruit humor and
then once those are set all we have to
do is transfer those back into the oven
for another about 10 to 12 minutes or
until nicely browned and looking
something like this
check it out those don't look bad and
then what you definitely want to do is
let this sit for at least 10 minutes
before trying to remove them otherwise
there will be issues so I did let my
cool about 10-15 minutes at which point
they were fairly easy to remove and my
peach Fein and Sears were done or as a
peach financier I really should find out
you know what a stickler I am for French
pronunciations and then once those had
completely cooled I transfer them onto a
serving platter and took a bunch of
pictures of course which I'll Photoshop
for the blog post but then I quickly
lost interest in the photography because
I really wanted to taste one of these
and by the way I'm really not a big
almond cake guy I mean I love peaches
I could eat a peach for hours but a
little peach and almond cake is not
necessarily something I would order but
these really are amazing
alright the outside is kind of crisp
around the edges the insides very rich
very buttery very moist and as you saw
all this was accomplished with a very
very simple recipe so if you're one of
these unfortunate souls that just never
has any luck with a cookie or pastry
recipe these will work and you could
take that to the bank so I really do
hope you give these a try head over to
food wishes comm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
you
